titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Visit in the forenoon to Mr: Van Staphorst, and to Mr: Sonsbeek. Found neither of them at home. Walk in the wood. Company not so numerous as usual.— Writing & Reading.

2. Received Letters this morning from The Secretary of the Treasury, from Mr: Pinckney at London, and from Mr: Bourne enclosing one from N. Freeman at Barnstable in America. Wrote in consequence of the former, to Messrs: Willink, Van Staphorst & Hubbard. Walk with Baron Bielfeld this forenoon. Conversation upon Government, and the rights of Man.

3. Wrote to the Secretary of State &c. A day of insipidity like so many others. Finished the reading of Torcy’s Memoirs, having before read D’Estrades and D’Avaux. Mr: D’Araujo says, we must henceforth not look back to any thing that has ever been done heretofore. There is not indeed the same advantage in possessing the principles and experience of able negotiations, because the present state of opinions and of practice, requires a different theory. Some use however may be made of this reading. At least it encreases the knowledge of History. And gives lessons of analogy which have some use for application for every position of affairs among men.

4. Dined at the Count de Löwenhielm, with a company principally diplomatic. The conversation at table principally turned upon the characters and talents of Women. After dinner Mr. D’Araujo had much to say of Rousseau. D’Araujo appears to be the character the most fairly and strongly marked among the Ministers now remaining here. He appears to have learning and information; and he is not unwilling to make it appear. He does it however without affectation and with all due civility. Count Löwenhielm spoke in terms of great respect and admiration of the President of the United States, and of the neutral system of policy, pursued by the American Government in the present War. Upon the observation that the Regent of Sweden, had pursued the same wise policy, he said that it was the example of America, which had encouraged it, and that the Swedes were obliged to the President of the United States for being the first to stand forward with that example, which encouraged them to imitation, and secured to them such great advantages, and such exemptions from the common distress in which all the nations now at War are involved.
Went to the Dutch Theatre, with Bielfeld. The Deserter was performed, tolerably.— Unwell this evening, and had a sleepless night.
5. Unwell again through the day.— Mr: Bourne was here and dined with us. Conversation upon the subject of our Commerce

6. Endeavouring to recruit by means of exercise. Dined with Mr: Scholten, The Baron de Spaen Mr: Bourne, and the french officer quartered in the house were of the Company. Mr: Bourne with me this Evening. Visit from Mr: Mersen in the forenoon. These people are very much dissatisfied with the present state of their public affairs.
7. Walking again this day. Mr: Bourne went to Rotterdam. Wrote to the Secretary of State. Time principally spent in reading.

8. Unwell after a restless night. Walk before dinner with Bielfeld. He says that Prussia, took the pains of establishing the Prince of Orange here, and merely gave the Country over to England. That Prussia had no influence at all. Every thing submitted to the british Ambassador.
The Princess of Orange herself proud and haughty as her character is, always paid her court very assiduously to the Ambassador’s wives, and it used to be perfectly disgusting to hear the insipid family details of Lady Aukland, about her children, which the Princess always received with great complaisance and attention.

9. Walk in the wood this forenoon. Met successively Messrs: Bielfeld & Middleton, Brito, Levsen, and finally Baron Schubart. Conversation principally upon the news of the day.— It becomes at length insipid. Mr: Brito, is the Secretary of the Portugueze legation, and appears to be a sensible well informed Man.— Mr: Bourne returned this Evening from Rotterdam, and called to see me, with Captain Hale, whom I formerly knew at Newbury-Port. He has had the misfortune of running a shore with his vessel on a bank off the Texel, and though she has since been got off, he finds a difficulty to recover part of his cargo, which the people on the coast, have as he says plundered upon pretence of saving it.

10. Captain Hale returned to Amsterdam. Saw Mr: Bourne in the morning, and again in the beginning of the Evening. Attended by invitation of General Dumonceau, the french Commandant here, a concert given by him at the Palace of the Old Court. The Representative of the People Ramel, the General in Chief Moreau, and the neutral foreign Ministers were there. The music excellent. After the concert some of the company made a party for a country-dance; feeling not perfectly well, I did not stay to supper.— The reveil du Peuple, a fashionable song against the system of terror, was sung. The words are tolerable, & the air not remarkably good. When I came home, from impatient curiosity to know the interesting intelligence from Paris, sat up too late reading the moniteur, the consequence of which was the loss of half a night’s rest. Every species of excess is severely forbidden me.

11. Visit from Mr: Bourne, who returns this day to Amsterdam. From Mr: Parry an Englishman who brought me a letter from Mr: Petrie. Appears to be a sensible man. Walk A.M. in the wood met Messrs: Bielfeld and Brito who renewed theirs at my request. Animated conversation relative to Syeyés, member of the National Convention.— Discretion! why so little attended to?— Called on Mr: Dumas in the Afternoon.— and on Mr: Parry, but found him not at home.— Long walk again. Find much exercise indispensable.

12. Visit to Mr: Parry, find him to be of the democratical creed. Walk in the wood &c. Letter to Mr: Faesch enclosing to him an Introduction to Mr: Monroe. received Letters this morning, from Mr: Pinckney, & papers from America.— Have read Duclos, Secret Memoirs; and find them at least very amusing. But the style is affected and the imitation of Tacitus too Evident. The book like many others serves to shew the nature of Courts, & the character of courtiers. It is a good book for Republicans.

13. Walk to Loosduinen. Walking alone is one of the miseries to which I have always condemned, and is the most cruel penance to which Nature has doomed me. This day it was rather
less tedious than usual, because I fell into a reverie which amused my reflections, and made the time appear rather shorter than I find to be commonly the case. Mr: Parry dined with us, and discovered more of his democratical and philosophical opinions.— Sent a packet this Evening to Mr: Faesch, for Mr: Pinckney at Paris.

14. Walk to Scheveling with Bielfeld. I find him still agreeable and entertaining. Our conversation was political, literary and critical, without sliding as it often does into the bottomless pitt of metaphysics. He told me some anecdotes about the second King of Prussia, the father of the late Frederic. He says that his correspondence with the Minister he then had, at the Hague, was never upon subjects of State, but consisted simply of commissions for purchases. At one time he writes for six pair of worsted stockings; at another for a cookmaid, and requires particularly that she should know how to stew prunes. He once ordered a Minister who was taking his Audience of departure going upon an Embassy to Sweeden, to purchase him a pair of leather breeches.— Speaking of the late King Bielfeld has not so high an opinion of his character as his reputation in the world would inspire.— Of the present Sovereign he says of course but little. His opinion is discoverable in his silence. He told me however that the characters and representations in the Secret History of Mirabeau, are all founded in truth, and accurate to admiration. At least as the Court was at that time. What it may be now I shall not pretend to say; said he. He says that the people of Prussia are extremely quiet. That a riot or insurrection is a thing which never enters the imagination of any of them; and he foresees that the Government has before it the prospect of a long and uninterrupted tranquility. For there are but three sources from which Insurrections and Revolutions, generally proceed. They are. Disorder of the public Finances. Religious persecution or judicial oppression. Whereas the finances in Prussia are in an excellent situation, or at least they have been. The present War may have produced some alteration in this respect.— All religions are tolerated, and the administration of Justice is Excellent. So that we have no reason to fear turbulence and rebellion. This theory appears very plausible, but it is always in vain to look forward into the History of Nations. The Course of Events is always so different from every thing foreseen, that one would think it is one of the professional employments of the Fates, to baffle all human penetration.
15. Mr: Parry paid a visit this forenoon. he sets out this day for Paris. Walk. met Mr: Brito, conversation with him.

16. Met Mr: Brito again.— Dined at Baron Schubart’s. Company not thoroughly assorted. There was a young french officer by the name of Sauvan, who amused himself and fatigued the Company during the whole dinner time. The officer quartered on Mr: Scholten, silent, modest unassuming served entirely to set him off. Almost all the company went in the Evening to the
french Comedy. The performances were tolerable.— Seated next to General Dumonceau, and to Mr: Brito.— The General informed me of the Peace concluded between France and Prussia. Brito, promised me the perusal of some English papers he has just received. We returned to Baron Schubart’s, passed the Evening, and supped. Mr: Levsen, beat me at Chess. After supper, the conversation became romantic and mystical, owing principally to the presence of the ladies, Madam Scholten & Madam Nederburgh, a beautiful young woman whose husband is in the East Indies. It ended in a discussion upon the common place of Love. Scholten and Spaen are both sensible men, and both have each of them has the opinion so common among men that his genius is universal, and extraordinary. Spaen is at the same time amiable in his manners, modest and pleasing in his address. Scholten values himself much upon his frankness and sincerity; upon his disregard of ceremony, and contempt of the little complaisance usual in Society. He sees a merit in indulging his own habits and his own feelings, while he prides himself in having no respect for those of others. He is jealous, suspicious, timid, vain and above all selfish. This last quality though not peculiar to him, characterizes him best. A dramatic writer might copy from him a model of egoism united with a good understanding. Spaen and he are both authors and even Poets; so they both of course dogmatized a little; not without warmth as they differed in their opinions. Scholten’s sentiments were such as might be expected in the creed of an old woman of the last century. The mystical union of souls, the impossibility of a second love; a state of pre-existence, a tutelary angel &c &c. Baron Schubart also confessed his belief in most of these articles. This Gentleman without pretending to so much genius, is very amiable and agreeable in Society. Benevolence of heart, is he says the first of all qualities in his opinion and I believe his practice agrees with his theory.— It was very late, when the company broke up.
17. Walk again this day with Bielfeld who is a little unwell. As we were returning we met Mr: Britto with whom I continued my walk. Letters this afternoon from London.

18. Unintelligible billet received from Mr: Scholten, on returning from my usual walk.— Refused. Spent the Evening however according to his invitation at his house. Company nearly the same as at Baron Schubart’s.—played Quadrille. Madame Nederburgh, lovely, poetical and pleasant as before. It shoul was decided after supper that every person who began to speak upon a political subject should pay a pawn. The offence and the punishment went round the table. Excepting Mr: Euler who escaped, and Mr: Scholten, who made a Principle of refusing to pay. He never plays at pawns. In the course of the conversation he affirmed something, his wife asked him to say so upon honour.— No.—he never pledges his Honour upon common occasions.— In both instances there was some reason, that but more of character. The amusement of playing pawns is puerile, insipid, & cheerless. Nor is it necessary to pledge one’s honour to trivial circumstances. But neither is it necessary or calculated to produce individual or social enjoyment, in the ordinary intercourse of convivial society, upon the most trivial occasions, and in cases where virtue and vice, are equally out of the question, to meet every effort to promote mirth or at least pastime, with the quills of a principle.
The redemption of the pawns terminated as usual in saluting the Ladies, a Ceremony from which the persons exempted would have derived as little satisfaction though not quite so much pain as was discovered by Mr: Scholten.— The next subject of amusement was a number of Charades & Bouts rimés produced by Madam Nederburgh. It was finally agreed that four bouts rimés should be taken to be filled by each of the Gentlemen present, and produced on Monday at Madame Nederburgh’s, when the Ladies should pronounce upon the merit of the best.— These diversions entertained us till 2 in the morning. This is not one of the occasions when “the Heart distrusting asks if this be joy.” There could be no room for such a question.

19. Bielfeld not having been of the company last Evening, I presumed it was owing to his indisposition, and called to see him, found him confined to his chamber. Mr: Brito sent me a number more of English newspapers. Spent the whole day in reading them. Letters from Boston. 1st:

20. Walk to Scheveling. Was caught in the rain. Evening and supper at Madame Nederburgh’s. The verses on the bouts-rimés were produced: and Bielfeld not having written, copied them all; to have them in the same hand-writing. After supper Madam Nederburgh gave the palm to a quatrain, of which Mr: Scholten appeared to be the author, and Madame Scholten to one of Mr: Spaen. Four new words were then given to be produced at the next meeting, and sometime after two, we were again dismissed.

21. Writing with great haste till about eleven o’clock, in order to prepare packets for Bremen and Hamburg, to go by Baron Schubart’s Courier. Sent them accordingly. Walk afterwards towards Delft, obliged to return by the prospect of Rain— Evening beautiful; long walk at the beginning of it.

22. Rainy day, confined of course to the house, find it difficult to take sufficient exercise.— Have read the private life of the Marechal de Richelieu.— It gives no exalted idea of Courts or of Courtiers.— Voltaire.— Works.
23.— Walk to Scheveling. Overtaken by the Rain.— Read & write too much. Tis an unavoidable fatality.
24. Weather still unpleasant. Walk to the gates of Delft. Letters from America. Day spent as usual; losing health, which ought to be restoring.

25. Walk in the rain, beyond Loosduinen. In vain.— Destiny all powerful.— Visit from Mr Van Sonsbeek, Deputy from the Province of Zeeland in the States-General; upon business before mentioned. Promised to write Mr: Bourne & wrote accordingly.

26. Weather very windy. Letter from Mr: Bourne. Visit to Mr: Van Sonsbeeck. not at home. Left the Commission, Instructions &c. from Mr: Bourne to Mr: Versluys as consular Agent. Walk to Scheveling. walk again towards Evening. At length find myself a little relieved.

27. Called to see Mr: Van Staphorst upon some business of Mr: Bourne, which he recommends to me by his letter received this morning. Conversation with Mr: Van Staphorst.— Cold enough in his manner.
At one single instant his muscles relaxed. Upon enquiry whether he was member of the Committee of finance,—“yes for my misfortune. It is a terrible duty that we have to perform.”— “The public are sensible that it is the department which requires the ablest men.”— He took it as a compliment; a single ray of satisfaction beamed upon his countenance, and the former chill then returned.— This is a man however of sensibility and of an excellent heart.— Called on Mr: Dumas, and found him packing up to move. He is sensible that all his high-flying political expectations are not like to be realized. Let us touch no more upon that string.

We could not accept the invitation to take the ride with our poetical company; but we pass’d the Evening at Baron Schubart’s and the bouts-rimés were again produced after supper. The preference as before fell upon Messrs: Spaen & Scholten, only the ladies changed the object of their respective votes. The best of the whole collection that I saw were of Mr: Spaen, but which he did not insert, and did not concur for the palm. The best of those that concurr’d were of Bielfeld, but they did not obtain the merited preference.— I speak with confidence, because I declined entering the lists this time.

Enquired of Mr Scholten, what books had been written and published, containing the best accounts of the Canals and dykes, of this Country. He said there were a great number, in Dutch, French and Latin, but that an academical dissertation of the Pensionary Van Bleiswick De Aggeribus, was one of the best.
28. Bielfeld called on me this forenoon; long walk with him. Visited the Gardens of the Old Court. Some account of the illuminated sect, and the mystics of Berlin.

29. Attended this morning a sale of books, and made a few purchases. Walk afterwards with Mr: Levsen. Met Bielfeld, and M. de Brito, and walked with them. On my return home, found Letters from my father and brother with newspapers to the 16th: of Feby: Reading them, till night. Health still indifferent.

30. Received this morning from Mr: Beeldemaker at Rotterdam, a packet from Mr: Johnson at London with English newspapers till the 22d. Billet from Mr: N. van Staphorst requesting to see me, called on him accordingly: he desired me to go to Amsterdam, and consult with his partners, upon the means of drawing from London the funds arrived there & destined to pay the instalment of the debt of the United States which will become due in June. I agreed to go accordingly, to-morrow morning. Letter from Mr: Bourne enclosing one for the Portugueze Minister, called and delivered it to him. Political conversation with him. He sent me the answer this Evening. Walk in the Wood; overtaken by the Rain. Prepared to go to-morrow morning by the Post-Waggon to Amsterdam.
